properties.Title: Cholera - Pakistan
properties.Reporting Agency: National IHR Focal Point of Pakistan
properties.Location: Pakistan, Sindh province, Balochistan province, Punjab province, Karachi city
properties.Risk Factors:
- The most affected districts are located in Karachi city which is an industrial center, as well as a transport hub with airport and seaport.
- In Balochistan province, there is suboptimal surveillance, limited access to safe drinking water, and limited access to health care.
- Affected areas are in proximity to areas with active cross-border movement with Afghanistan and Iran.

properties.Title: Multi-country monkeypox outbreak: situation update
properties.Location: Region of the Americas, European Region, Eastern Mediterranean Region, Western Pacific Region, WHO African Region, Ghana, United States of America
properties.Risk Factors:
- Being part of extended sexual networks
- Close or direct physical contact with infectious lesions or mucocutaneous sores, including during sexual activity
- Being a health worker without appropriate personal protective equipment
- Being a part of vulnerable groups like children and immunocompromised individuals, including persons with poorly controlled HIV
- Pregnancy
- Age over 42 to 50 years old with potentially waned immunity from smallpox vaccination
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Direct Contact (e.g., face-to-face, skin-to-skin, mouth-to-mouth, mouth-to-skin)
- Sexual Contact
- Contact with Lesions, Body Fluids, and Contaminated Materials

properties.Title: Multi-country monkeypox outbreak: situation update
properties.Location: Americas, Africa, Europe, Eastern Mediterranean, Western Pacific
properties.Risk Factors:
- Participation in extended sexual networks, particularly among men who self-identify as men who have sex with men
- Close or direct physical contact with infectious lesions or mucocutaneous ulcers including during sexual activity, respiratory droplets, or contact with contaminated materials
- Health workers being in contact with a case while not wearing appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE)
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Direct contact, including sexual contact, with an infected person
- Close contact with lesions, body fluids, respiratory droplets of an infected person
- Contact with infected materials from an infected person
properties.Summary:
Country:
Chad

Event Type:
Novel outbreak - Epidemic

Number of Countries Affected:
5

Reporting Agency:
World Health Organization

Modes of Transmission:
- Direct contact, including sexual contact, with an infected person
- Close contact with lesions, body fluids, respiratory droplets of an infected person
- Contact with infected materials from an infected person

Risk Factors:
- Participation in extended sexual networks, particularly among men who self-identify as men who have sex with men
- Close or direct physical contact with infectious lesions or mucocutaneous ulcers including during sexual activity, respiratory droplets, or contact with contaminated materials

properties.Title: Multi-country monkeypox outbreak: situation update
properties.Location: Nigeria, WHO European Region, WHO African Region, Region of the Americas, Eastern Mediterranean Region, Western Pacific Region
properties.Risk Factors:
- First and significant risk factor is the "geographically widespread outbreak" in different regions, notably in the European Region, pointing to the possibility of high transmission and spread.
- Second risk factor is the human-to-human transmission via "direct contact with infectious skin or mucocutaneous lesions, respiratory droplets, indirect contact from contaminated objects or materials," and "vertical transmission."
- Third risk factor is the increased "health impact with wider dissemination in vulnerable groups," including children, young adults, and immunocompromised individuals like those with "uncontrolled HIV infection."

properties.Title: Ebola virus disease - Democratic Republic of the Congo
properties.Location: Democratic Republic of the Congo, Mbandaka, Wangata, Equateur, Mama Balako, Libiki, Motema Pembe, Kinshasa, Bolenge
properties.Risk Factors:
- Exposure to an animal host or from persistent virus in certain body fluids of survivors
- Environmental and socio-economic factors including poverty, community mistrust, weak health systems, and political instability 
- Challenges in terms of access and security, epidemiological surveillance, coupled with the emergence of COVID-19, as well as other ongoing outbreaks like cholera and measles.
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Wildlife-to-human transmission from contact with infected fruit bats or non-human primates and consumption of their raw meat
- Human-human transmission from direct contact with body fluids
- Transmission from virus persistent in some bodily fluids of EVD survivors

properties.Title: Dengue in Rohingya refugee/Forcibly Displaced Myanmar Nationals (FDMN) camps in Cox’s Bazar - Bangladesh
properties.Reporting Agency: Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research
properties.Location: Bangladesh, Cox’s Bazar district, Rohingya refugee/FDMN camps, Ukhia Upazila, Teknaf Upazila, Dhaka
properties.Risk Factors:
- Inadequate access to potable water or quality sanitation
- High levels of global acute malnutrition (GAM) in children under five years
- Persistent transmission of various diseases such as acute watery diarrhoea (AWD), cholera, diphtheria, measles, varicella, and skin infections
- Limited hospital capacity and straining of healthcare services due to an influx of patients
- Population movements due to the relaxation of COVID-19 related movement restrictions
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Mosquito bite from an infected Aedes species mosquito
- Mosquito breeding near human habitation
- Mosquito life cycle sustained through biting infected individuals

properties.Title: Ebola virus disease - Democratic Republic of the Congo
properties.Reporting Agency: Ministry of Health of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
properties.Location: Democratic Republic of the Congo, Beni, North Kivu, Equateur province, Goma, Kinshasa, Ituri, South Kivu
properties.Risk Factors:
- First case was hospitalized at the health facility for 23 days without being diagnosed with EVD and died before EVD was confirmed, posing a risk of spread in the health facility. 
- The virus can persist in some bodily fluids of EVD survivors, and secondary transmissions resulting from exposure to these body fluids have been documented. 
- Protests against security measure and the United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission increase the risk of refusal of outbreak control measures, thereby increasing the possibility of disease spread.

properties.Title: Dengue - Nepal
properties.Reporting Agency: Epidemiology and Disease Control Division of the Ministry of Health and Population
properties.Location: Nepal, Bagmati, Kathmandu, Lalitpur, Makwanpur
properties.Risk Factors:
- The population may be at risk of re-infection of dengue, which can lead to serious complications if not managed promptly and correctly.
- There is limited hospital capacity in-country and limited access to and use of health care services, likely leading to an increase in severe dengue cases and case-fatality rates.
- Dengue cases are expanding out of the lowland areas typically suitable for the breeding of Aedes mosquitoes to higher elevations, potentially due to climate changes and rapid urbanization.
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Mosquito bites from infected mosquitoes
- Infected mosquito spreading the virus in households 
- Infected mosquito spreading the virus in neighbourhoods

properties.Title: Malaria - Pakistan
properties.Reporting Agency: The text does not provide the name of the agency that initially reported the outbreak.
properties.Location: Pakistan, Balochistan, Sindh
properties.Risk Factors:
- Intense transmission of disease in districts located in regions bordering the Islamic Republic of Iran and Afghanistan and along the coastal belt in Sindh and Balochistan provinces.
- High population movement between Pakistan and its border countries (Afghanistan and the Islamic Republic of Iran), especially in districts affected by floods.
- Limited access to health facilities, lack of sufficient healthcare workers, and inadequate medical supplies exist, exacerbating the risk of severe health impacts from diseases like malaria.

properties.Summary:
Country:
Iran

Event Type:
Existing epidemic - Epidemic

Number of Countries Affected:
4

Reporting Agency:
National Institute of Health-Islamabad

Modes of Transmission:
- Mosquito vector breeding close to human habitation
- Human-vector contact in residences, schools, and hospitals
- Outdoor activities exposing skin to mosquito bites

Risk Factors:
- Abnormal monsoon rainfall and unprecedented floods creating favorable habitats for mosquitoes to breed.
- Damage to health facilities and displacement of people limiting access to healthcare and medical treatment.
- High population movement between Pakistan and bordering countries, potentially facilitating the spread of diseases like dengue fever.

properties.Title: Rift Valley Fever - Mauritania
properties.Location: Mauritania, Mali, Senegal, Algeria, Tintane, Hodh El Gharbi, Adrar, Assaba, Guidimakha, Hodh Echargui, Tagant, Tiris Zemmour, Tr
properties.Risk Factors:
- Transmission through carrier mosquito bites, contact with contaminated blood or tissues, and during the slaughter of animals
- Precarious environmental conditions, inadequate sanitation services, and high animal density
- The abundant rainfall recorded this year and flooding, combined with the dumping of waste tires, used containers and garbage, which enhance the proliferation of vector breeding sites.
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Contact with blood or organs of infected animals
- Unsafe consumption of infected animal products (blood, raw milk, or tissues)
- Local transmission via mosquito vectors

properties.Location: Saudi Arabia, Riyadh, Gassim, Makka Al Mukarramah
properties.Risk Factors:
- Contact with dromedaries or their products (for example, consumption of camel’s raw milk)
- Exposure in a healthcare setting
- Travel to areas where MERS-CoV is circulating, particularly the Middle East and Arabian Peninsula
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Human-to-human transmission in healthcare settings
- Care to patients with acute respiratory infection (droplet transmission)
- Performing aerosol-generating procedures (airborne transmission)

properties.Title: Dengue - Bangladesh
properties.Reporting Agency: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare of Bangladesh
properties.Location: Bangladesh, Dhaka, Chattogram, Khulna
properties.Risk Factors:
- Untimely rainfall and favorable climate conditions leading to increased density of Aedes mosquito population.
- Storage of water in containers such as buckets and pots within homes, offering breeding sites for Aedes mosquitos.
- Increased movement of people due to lifted travel restrictions, contributing to potential dengue transmission cycles.
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Mosquito bite after feeding on dengue-infected individual
- Mosquito vector breeding close to human habitation
- Human-vector contact in various locations (residences, workplaces, schools, hospitals)

properties.Title: Circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) - Indonesia
properties.Location: Indonesia, Pidie district, Aceh province, North Sumatera, West Sumatera, Riau, Papua province
properties.Risk Factors:
- Low polio vaccination coverage in Aceh and other provinces in Indonesia
- Susceptibility of the population to poliovirus type 2 after switching from trivalent oral polio vaccine (tOVP) to bOPV in April 2016 combined with low uptake of inactivated polio vaccine (IPV)
- Sub-optimal surveillance capacity and vaccine hesitancy among the at-risk population

properties.Title: Yellow fever - African Region (AFRO)
properties.Location: Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Côte d'Ivoire, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, Kenya, Niger, Nigeria, Republic of the Congo, Sierra Leone, Uganda, Gabon
properties.Risk Factors:
- Gaps in routine immunization
- Presence in locations with little or no underlying immunity (especially near urban areas or areas with no history of yellow fever vaccination)
- Security and access challenges, including population movement and security constraints in affected areas
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Transmission through Aedes mosquitos in urban & densely populated areas
- Infected returning travellers may establish local cycles of transmission 
- Transmission possible during day and early evening due to active mosquito vector

Number of Countries Affected:
12

Reporting Agency:
World Health Organization

Modes of Transmission:
- Transmission through Aedes mosquitos in urban & densely populated areas
- Infected returning travellers may establish local cycles of transmission 
- Transmission possible during day and early evening due to active mosquito vector

Risk Factors:
- Gaps in routine immunization
- Presence in locations with little or no underlying immunity (especially near urban areas or areas with no history of yellow fever vaccination)
- Security and access challenges, including population movement and security constraints in affected areas

properties.Title: Cholera - Malawi
properties.Reporting Agency: Ministry of Public Health of Malawi
properties.Location: Malawi, Machinga, Mangochi, Blantyre, Lilongwe
properties.Risk Factors:
- Seasonality, particularly the onset of the rainy season from November through May, which traditionally sees an increase in cholera cases
- Poor WASH (Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene) capacities in the affected districts, specifically in fishing communities along Lake Malawi
- Presence of unvaccinated sub-districts and districts, coupled with inadequate capacity for case management and diagnosis in the affected areas leading to delayed case detection and poor health outcomes

properties.Title: Ebola disease caused by Sudan ebolavirus – Uganda
properties.Location: Uganda, Bunyangabu, Jinja, Kagadi, Kampala, Kassanda, Kyegegwa, Masaka, Mubende, Wakiso
properties.Risk Factors:
- Presence of the filoviruses in the wild animal reservoir in the region
- Challenges in terms of epidemiological surveillance, infection prevention and control programs and practices in health care settings
- Impact of other ongoing outbreaks (such as Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF), Rift Valley fever, yellow fever, cholera, and measles) and the COVID-19 pandemic
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Wildlife-to-human transmission through contact with infected wild animals or consumption of their raw meat
- Human-to-human transmission through direct or close contact with people showing Ebola symptoms, especially with their bodily fluids
- Transmission through health care amplification, such as not adhering to infection prevention and control (IPC) measures within a health care system.
properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Measles - Nepal
properties.Location: Nepalgunj sub-metropolitan city, Banke district, Surkhet, Bardiya, Kailali, Kanchanpur, Bajura, Dang, Mahottari, Sunsari, Morang, L
properties.Risk Factors:
- The presence of a large number of migrants and mobile populations, making them vulnerable to measles infection due to likely missed routine immunizations.
- The outbreak occurring in an area with a porous border between India and Nepal, increasing the potential for spreading the disease.
- Low vaccination coverage due to COVID-19 pandemic-related disruptions, resulting in an immunity gap in the population.

properties.Risk Factors:

- Suboptimal national measles vaccination coverage with 86% coverage, below the required 95% to achieve population herd immunity
- High rates of HIV/AIDS and TB, which can worsen the clinical picture of measles, in the South African population

properties.Location: Germany, Türkiye, Austria, Switzerland

- Improper use of pharmaceutical products containing botulinum neurotoxins (type A or type B), including off-label use in bariatric cases
- Insufficient warnings of toxic effects and inadequately addressed risks in the patient consent process for treatments involving botulinum neurotoxins.

properties.Title: Marburg virus disease - United Republic of Tanzania
properties.Reporting Agency: Ministry of Health of the United Republic of Tanzania
properties.Location: United Republic of Tanzania, Bukoba district, Kagera region, Goziba Island, Lake Victoria, Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Equatorial Guinea, Ghana, Guinea, Angola, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Kenya, South Africa
properties.Risk Factors:
- Cross-border population movements may increase the risk of disease spread
- The Marburg virus has been isolated from fruit bats (Roussettus aegyptiacus) in the region, which could serve as a disease reservoir 
- Inadequate human, financial, and material resources to implement response interventions can exacerbate the risk of spread and impact of the outbreak

- Transmission in healthcare settings 
- Contact with contaminated surfaces and objects

Number of Countries Affected:
11

Reporting Agency:
Ministry of Health of the United Republic of Tanzania

Modes of Transmission:
- Direct contact with blood and/or other bodily fluids of infected people
- Transmission in healthcare settings 
- Contact with contaminated surfaces and objects

Risk Factors:
- Cross-border population movements may increase the risk of disease spread
- The Marburg virus has been isolated from fruit bats (Roussettus aegyptiacus) in the region, which could serve as a disease reservoir 
- Inadequate human, financial, and material resources to implement response interventions can exacerbate the risk of spread and impact of the outbreak

properties.Title: Marburg virus disease - Equatorial Guinea
properties.Location: Equatorial Guinea, Bata, Litoral province, Dakar, Senegal, Ebebiyin, Evinayong, Nsok Nsomo, Nsork, Centro Sur, Kie Ntem, Wele
properties.Risk Factors:
- The most populated city and economic hub of Equatorial Guinea, Bata, has confirmed cases of MVD which increases the risk of disease spread.
- Insufficient infection prevention and control measures, as demonstrated by MVD cases reported among healthcare workers.
- Frequent population movements and porous land borders, with suboptimal surveillance at land entry points and numerous uncontrolled paths or trails along the border with Cameroon and Gabon also contribute to the risk.

properties.Title: Measles - Indonesia
properties.Location: Indonesia, West Java, Central Papua, Banten, Aceh, North Sumatera, Riau, Riau Islands, West Sumatera, Java-Bali, East Java
properties.Risk Factors:
- Likely under-detection and under-reporting of measles cases due to non-availability of laboratory reagents for confirmation of cases.
- Low MCV1 and MCV2 coverage in most provinces, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic (2020-2021); 28% of the birth cohort in 2021 have not received any measles vaccination.
- Low measles-containing vaccine supplemental immunization activities (MCV-SIA) coverage in 2022, especially in high-risk provinces, tied to vaccine hesitancy and limited capacity for outbreak response immunization (ORI).

properties.Title: Middle East Respiratory Syndrome - United Arab Emirates

- Through aerosol-generating procedures in healthcare settings

properties.Title: Circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) - Kenya
properties.Location: Hagadera refugee camp, Kenya, Banadir, Somalia, Fafi district, Garissa county, Afmadhow, Lower Juba, southern Somalia
properties.Risk Factors:
- Overcrowded living conditions in refugee camps
- High rate of malnutrition
- Poor water and sanitation facilities
- Frequent population movements with Somalia
- High prevalence of zero dose children among new arrivals from middle and lower Juba, Somalia
- Sub-optimal surveillance performance
- Low population immunity
- Inadequate routine immunization levels in some areas
- Large-scale population movements
- Gaps in routine immunization coverage and inadequate outbreak response vaccination
- Decreased immunization rates related to disruption in routine and campaign immunization during the COVID-19 pandemic

properties.Title: Dengue - Bangladesh
properties.Reporting Agency: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare of Bangladesh
properties.Location: Bangladesh, Dhaka, Chattogram, Barisal, Sylhet
properties.Risk Factors:
- There is an ongoing rapidly increasing number of cases and deaths due to dengue, with the peak not yet reached
- DENV2 has been identified as the predominant circulating serotype, potentially resulting in higher numbers of severe cases as a result of a second infection with a heterologous serotype
- Climate change and heavy rains in neighboring countries increase the likelihood of vector-borne disease transmission
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Mosquito bites from DENV-infected mosquitoes
- Spread of virus from mosquito population within households and neighborhoods 
- Virus transmission through mosquito vector breeding sites near human habitation
properties.Summary:

properties.Location: Kozhikode district, Kerala, India
properties.Risk Factors:
- Unknown exposure of the first case in this outbreak
- Presence of a bat population which harbors Nipah virus, acting as a potential source of infection
- High reported case fatality rate (33.3%) and high number of contacts
properties.Modes of Transmission:
- Bat-to-human transmission via contaminated date palm juice or fruit
- Animal-to-human transmission through contact with infected domestic animals
- Human-to-human transmission via close unprotected physical contact
